option.name: title_text
option.value: Promoting Active Participation in the Online Classroom

string_table.name: npxnabnsnfns10111001101
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Promoting Active Participation in the Online Classroom

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Creating a vibrant and engaging learning environment online can be challenging, but it's absolutely crucial for student success. Today, we'll explore practical strategies, address common obstacles, and highlight helpful EdTech tools to empower you to foster active participation in your virtual classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Active participation isn't just about showing up; it's about students being mentally and actively involved in the learning process. It's about them asking questions, sharing ideas, collaborating with peers, and constructing their own understanding. When students can take ownership in their learning, it makes the content special to them and retention increases. In online learning, where passive consumption can be tempting, active participation is even more critical. It combats isolation, deepens learning, and builds a stronger sense of community. Engaged students are more likely to be motivated, retain information, and succeed in their online courses." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Several challenges can hinder active participation in online settings. Students might feel shy or intimidated to speak up in a virtual environment. Technical difficulties can disrupt the flow of interaction. Distractions at home can make it hard for students to focus. And sometimes, students simply aren't sure how to effectively participate online. It's our job as instructors to anticipate these challenges and proactively address them." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Design learning activities that encourage active involvement. Incorporate a variety of interactive elements, such as polls, quizzes, and short answer questions, into your online lessons. Use breakout rooms during live sessions to facilitate small group discussions. Pose open-ended questions that encourage critical thinking and diverse perspectives. Provide opportunities for students to share their work and receive feedback from their peers. Think about how you can create activities that are relevant to students' lives and interests, making the learning experience more engaging and meaningful." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text=" But don’t worry, you don’t always have to be the one creating! Several EdTech tools can be invaluable in promoting active participation and student creation. Platforms like Seesaw allow students to create short video responses, fostering a more personal and engaging form of communication. Tools like Padlet create collaborative spaces for brainstorming and resource sharing. Interactive quiz platforms like Kahoot! or Blooket can make learning fun and competitive. For synchronous sessions, features like polls and chat in Zoom or Google Meet can keep students actively involved. Don't forget the power of intentional discussion forums within your LMS; these provide a space for asynchronous discussion and allow students to reflect on their learning at their own pace." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="For students to actively participate, it is important to set clear expectations. Explicitly communicate how students can participate actively in the course and what constitutes meaningful engagement. Provide clear guidelines for online discussions and group projects. Offer support and guidance to students who are struggling to participate. Be patient and understanding, and remember that some students may need extra encouragement to feel comfortable participating online." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Creating an actively participating online classroom requires intentional effort and a variety of strategies. By building a strong sense of community, designing engaging activities, utilizing appropriate EdTech tools, and providing clear expectations and support, you can empower your students to become active and engaged learners in the online environment. Remember to be flexible, experiment with different approaches, and continuously reflect on what works best for your students. Promoting student curiosity, student choice, and content personalization is critical in promoting active participation in an online classroom. Active participation is a key ingredient for online learning success, and it's within your reach to cultivate it in your virtual classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
